results.title: Diabetes
results.creator_credit: Milan Chvostek and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Various researchers explain the nature of diabetes; it differs when it attacks children and adults.A mother and daughter comment on the effect the illness has on the latter and how through family and outside support she copes with it. An adult man discusses his illness and Dr. Best explains, with the help of old photographs, how he and Dr. Banting discovered insulin - which we see being manufactured.
results.description:

results.title: Out of the mouths of babes
results.creator_credit: Heather Cook and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Focuses on Peter and Jill de Villiers, two Harvard researchers, and their contention that knowledge of a language is innate in humans and develops as the child matures biologically. Includes interviews with both scientists and highlights their work. Suitable for tertiary/teacher level.

results.title: The Invisible reef
results.creator_credit: Milan Chvostek and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Through the modern-day magic of micro-photography, viewers are led deep into the mysterious folds of the world’s oldest known eco-system - the coral reef. Here, cameras study how a coral reef is formed and perpetuated by a complex system of recycling that makes use of all available energy and materials. But more then that they find fantasy in a biological wonderland. Narrated by William Whitehead.
results.description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Through the modern-day magic of micro-photography, viewers are led deep into the mysterious folds of the world’s oldest known eco-system - the coral reef. Here, cameras study how a coral reef is formed and perpetuated by a complex system of recycling that makes use of all available energy and materials. But more then that they find fantasy in a biological wonderland. Narrated by William Whitehead.

results.title: Microscope: making it big
results.creator_credit: Richard Longley and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
A film study of the microscope, putting it into scientific and historical perspective from Van Leeuwenhoek’s 17th century observations through an amateurish magnifying glass to the modern monsters that make a flea seem incredibly long. This is largely a pictorial film suited to students viewing simple microscopic organisms from pond water with a reasonable monocular microscope for the first time. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Vision of Galileo
results.creator_credit: Italo Costa and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Visits the cities in which Galileo lived and worked: Pisa, Florence, Padua, Venice and Rome. Also repeats some of his experiments and explains them in a script based largely on Galileo’s own writings. With David Suzuki. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.description:

results.title: Newborn
results.creator_credit: Heather Cook and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Examines the various inborn abilities, reflexes and working senses of newborn babies. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Sleep
results.creator_credit: Heather Cook and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
We spend a third of our lives asleep. This program looks at the structure of sleep and disturbances to that structure, such as nightmares and sleepwalking, sleep disorders such as narcolepsy and what happens when our normal daily patterns of sleep and wakefulness, day and night are interrupted.

results.title: The Sexes: what's the difference?
results.creator_credit: Heather Cook, Roman Bittman and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Examines the question of whether or not there are certain basic biological differences between males and females. The assertion that the socialisation of children totally determines their social behaviour and attitudes is disputed. Environmental factors may not be the sole determinants of sex roles. Suitable for middle and upper secondary and teacher/tertiary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Heather Cook, Roman Bittman and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
